title: Communication between widgets and Service Management
content:
The custom widgets can communicate with Service Management through the following methods:

  • ESMHoneycomb object (for interaction with Service Portal)
  • Service Management REST APIs
  • CSS theming variables (for Service Portal)

Interact with Service Portal through ESMHoneycomb

Service Portal shares a range of commonly used data and call-back functions with the custom widgets. When you build your custom widgets, you can use these data and functions to get basic information and perform simple interactions with Service Portal.

In Service Portal, all these objects and functions are put in a globally accessible static object named ESMHoneycomb, which can be used in your JavaScript source file.

Shared data

The shared JavaScript objects are static and read-only. Modifications on the shared object won't be allowed and won't work in Service Portal.

List of information object in ESMHoneycomb:

Name Structure Description
User {
    Locale: 'en',
    Upn: 'admin'
}

[object] Current user information.

User locale code is a valid two-letter ISO language code.

Upn is current logged in user's login name.
TenantId "100000002" [string] Current tenant ID

Usage example: Get ID of the currently logged-in tenant

// ESMHoneycomb is a global object
    const tenantID = ESMHoneycomb.TenantId;
    console.log(`Current tenant: ${tenantID}`);

Available call-backs

List of call-back functions in ESMHoneycomb:

Name Parameter Description
open

url: string

target: string

features: object  
Note: This parameter is inherited from the window.open function

A wrap of the window.open function. Provide additional security warning based on the Authorized domains setting.

Note: This function is only available for external links in HTML-typed widgets.
navigate

dest: string

params: object

 Navigate to a location in Service Portal. See the In-page navigation section for details.

NotificationCenter.info

NotificationCenter.warn

NotificationCenter.error

 message: string Show notification bar in Service Portal with a string message.
getXSRFToken A helper function used to get the XSRF-TOKEN string from the cookie in X-Xsrf-Token header of POST and PUT requests. You may use this function in case you need to assemble requests manually.

Usage example: Open an external link

It is recommended that you use the function below instead of the native window.open function in your component JavaScript code as well as from HTML-typed widgets.

    // open Google website
    window.ESMHoneycomb.open('https://g.co');

Usage example: Perform an external navigation

For security concerns, it is recommended that you bind the click event for the <a> elements to this function to perform an external navigation.  

<a onclick="myFunction()">Try it</a>

<script>
function myFunction() {
  window.ESMHoneycomb.open('https://www.microfocus.com');
}
</script>

Usage example: Show warning message in notification bar

   // push warning message
   ESMHoneycomb.NotificationCenter.warn('Notification Center test warning message.');

In-page navigation:

  • Service Portal is a single-page application (SPA). The use of relative URL navigation could trigger a reload. To perform in-page navigation, you can use the navigate call-back function mentioned in the Available call-backs section for better user experience.
  • It's highly recommended that you use the navigate and open call-back functions to perform in-page navigation and open new browsing context for your hyperlinks (<a> elements) defined in the custom widget. (For HTM-typed widgets, you're not encouraged to define <a> link directly in the custom widget.)

There are some pre-defined destinations for custom widgets to navigate and reach some most often used records, such as offerings, articles and requests. You can use the navigate call-back function in the ESMHoneycomb global object for such purpose.

ESMHoneycomb.navigate(dest, param);
  • dest: The first parameter, dest, is the name of defined destinations.
  • param: The second parameter, param, is the required data for this navigate, such as the offering ID.

Destinations for navigation:

Destination Parameter Description
Home null Navigate to the Service Portal landing page.
Offering {
    id: <offering id>
}		 Navigate to the offering page with the given ID.
Article {
id: <article id>
}		 Navigate to the view page of the Article record.
News {
    id: <news id>
}		 Navigate to the view page of the News record.
Request {
    id: <request id>
}		 Navigate to the tracking page of the Request .
Approval {
    entityId: <approval entity id>
}		 Navigate to My Approvals and expand the approval with given ID (if passed).
The entityId parameter is optional.
Idea {
    id: <idea id>
}		 Navigate to the details page of the Idea record.
ExternalApp {
    id: <full page widget id>,
    appName: <app name>
}		 Navigate to a Full page widget. The appName parameter is optional.
Regarding how to get the Widget ID, see the use case for Full page widgets.

Example:

You can assign a click event to a hyperlink or a button to trigger navigation:

   // Bind to a link: <a id="offering_12345">New iPhone</a>
   document.querySelector('#offering_12345').addEventListener('click', () => {
       ESMHoneycomb.navigate('Offering', { id: '12345' });
    });

Or, you can firstly create a Full page widget (see the use case for Full page widgets), then add the access link from another custom widget, such as a Landing page widget or a Sidebar widget, by implementing the following HTML with the navigate call-back function in ESMHoneycomb:

ESMHoneycomb.navigate('ExternalApp', { id: '621eb954f3cf02dc67540ef1', appName: 'Profitability Report' });

Use case – Display internal links

In addition to the use case of adding a custom widget that links to an external web page (see Display external links), you can also use the navigation functionality in ESMHoneycomb to display internal links from Service Portal.

You may simply replace the code of the <body> section from Display external links with the following example code to create a custom widget with internal link.

<body>
  <div class="side-container">
    <div class="side-title">Useful Links</div>
    <div class="side-list">
      <div class="link-item">
        <a title="Profitability Report" data-dest="ExternalApp" data-url="621eb954f3cf02dc67540ef1">Profitability Report</a>
        <span title="Customer Profitability Sample PBIX">Customer Profitability Sample PBIX</span>
      </div>
      <div class="link-item">
        <a title="ITOM PRACTITIONER PORTAL" data-dest="url" data-url="/">ITOM PRACTITIONER PORTAL</a>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div>

  <script>
    document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', () => {
      document.querySelectorAll('a[data-url]').forEach((aEle) => aEle.addEventListener('click', (event) => {
        if (event.target.getAttribute('data-dest') === 'ExternalApp') {
          // navigate to Service Management full-page widget
          window.ESMHoneycomb.navigate('ExternalApp', { id: event.target.getAttribute('data-url') });
        } else if (event.target.getAttribute('data-dest') === 'url') {
          // safe open external link
          window.ESMHoneycomb.open(event.target.getAttribute('data-url'));
        }
      }));
    });
  </script>
</body>

In the example code above, the following link-item section is added to the side-list section. This link will finally navigate the user to another page in Service Portal. This element is slightly different with the standard syntax. There is not an href attribute, instead, the information is add in another two custom attributes, data-dest and data-url, which will be used in JavaScript code when handling click event on this element.
Note that data-url is the UUID of the destination page generated from Power BI widget example.

<div class="link-item">
    <a title="Profitability Report" data-dest="ExternalApp" data-url="621eb954f3cf02dc67540ef1">Profitability Report</a>
    <span title="Customer Profitability Sample PBIX">Customer Profitability Sample PBIX</span>
</div>

To handle the click event on each link item, a small snippet of JavaScript code is also added in the example code, which is used to perform the navigation after a click event fired.

The following code section is aimed to bind the click event to each <a> element after the DOM content is loaded:

    document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', () => {
      document.querySelectorAll('a[data-url]').forEach((aEle) => aEle.addEventListener('click', (event) => {
        ……
      }));
    });

The following code section defines how to response to the click event on one-link item. If the destination is an external application in Service Portal, the script will call the ESMHoneycomb.navigate function with proper parameters. Otherwise, the script will call the ESMHoneycomb.open function to open the online documentation.

if (event.target.getAttribute('data-dest') === 'ExternalApp') {
  // navigate to Service Management full-page widget
  window.ESMHoneycomb.navigate('ExternalApp', { id: event.target.getAttribute('data-url') });
} else if (event.target.getAttribute('data-dest') === 'url') {
  // safe open external link
  window.ESMHoneycomb.open(event.target.getAttribute('data-url'));
}
The ESMHOneycomb.open function is not mandatory to be used here, but is recommended. For security concerns, this function will pop up a warning message before performing the navigation if the external domain is not defined as a trusted domain.

Use REST APIs

Custom widgets may call Service Management APIs directly as the currently logged-in user. API invocation may be achieved using the native fetch method or other REST clients depending on which library or framework you choose to implement the custom widget. For example, you can use HttpClient to send requests if your Web Component is implemented with Angular framework. If your Web Component is developed by React or Vue, you can choose Axios as the HTTP client.

Make sure that the target audience of the custom widget has the right permission to access data from the APIs used in this widget. Also, you may need to handle the forbidden exception that may return from API calls.

Usage example:

Retrieve incidents via EMS REST API with native fetch method.

const tenantId = ESMHoneycomb.TenantId;
   fetch(`/rest/${tenantId}/ems/Incident?layout=Id,Status,OwnedByPerson,OwnedByPerson.Name,OwnedByPerson.Email`,
     {
         method: 'GET'
     }).then(
         (response) => {
             // do something with Response data
         }
     );

In your HTML contents, be sure to use absolute URI of the API which begins with a slash character ("/"), or make sure the base location of your HTML document is root of the current environment:
base href="/">

Accessing Service Portal theme settings

The Service Portal theming functionality is based on CSS variables, which can be shared with the custom widgets.

To keep a consistency look and feel between native widgets and custom widgets in Service Portal, for the Web Components or HTML contents based custom widgets, there are CSS theming variables from Service Portal that may be leveraged. You can choose to use appropriate variables to decorate custom widget templates.

For example, if you would like to set a background color to the same logo background color as in Service Portal, you can use the CSS variable as below:

.an-element {
    background-color: var(--logoBackgroundColor, #00264b);
}

It' also recommended that you set a fallback value in case the variable happens to be unavailable.
